The annual national convention Of the National Newspaper Pub
convened last Monday the hunderbd Hotel
Mbrae suburb Of San Francisco, California from
the International Airport.


More than 100 publishers and of related activities
tended There many national figures from walks Of
friends who
more than a decade.


The Los Angeles Sentinel headed by Leon Washington and the
Reporter published by DR.. Carlton Goodet
cohosts Both be congratulated for providing
interesting convention.


happy my friend John Sengsacke my oldest
friends America He Of the first met John heads
the Chicago Defender papers, which includes daily.


Another friend long standing Dr. Frank L. Stanley @ pub
Usher the Louisville Defender elected president
Frank during World War H. when he making survey
Germany and attached the American forces In
Europe.


Whitney Young, r national director Of the Urban
League renewed and talked at length about
the growth Of the league.


Grant REYNOLDS the National Republican Party chair
director of the National Democratic
and have been friends for years. We agreed
political stage will be full of action the
lions approach.

fornia fair employment practices commission.

Rumford, a former Phoencan, rewarding, too.

Of work. We discussed Of the friends we

interesting schedule that would take than
space provides discuss 1t fully.

We visited I. Magnin' s and Saks
Fifth Avenue. We overstayed our
time and Edward had to catch
taxi from the hotel uptown for
business appointment at the Mark
Hopkins. Needless to say, when
he failed to wait long enough for
me and returned by taM--l wasn't
too happy. However. all is fair
in love. war and on vacation.


While in San Francisco our
trip was made more enjoyable by
meeting SO many interesting per-
sons. They made the convention
outstanding and DR.. and Mrs.

For nearly tho weeks the ROADS and rivers
in and around PhiLQde lbbia, Mississippi haze
been thoroughly searched. The object Of local
and national LAM enforcement groups are three
young men, one Negro and tuO0 whites, uOhO
we're in the area for summer U0teT regis
ty0tiom program among the Negro citizens.


The trio had been arrested and jailed on
a traffic charge and the sheriff reported
they had been released. No trace OF the young
men has been found, however, a foYeboding
sight, their chaYyed vehicle s0as located.


The clearance Of the federal ciUiI rights
bin BY Congress is almost completed, but
the bonabimgs Of Negro homes and churches,
the beatings and na0inpi'agS Of Negroes and
sympathetic whites continue.


While men and women Of int diligence
styive to- bring about improved conditions be-
tween the races in many areas, the outlook IN
Mississippi is dim tndeed. The hearts and
nsi,sds of those who Hve there must be altered
before q brighter day W5u appear.


No one should believe that the DISAPPEAR
ance Of these three men was done wstho~t the
knowledge of the sheriff uho released them
from JAIL The secret societies for unite
supremacy are formed by the veTy people
who swear to uphold LAM and justice Cthe1r
OaOn kind.


Senseless killings are shocking, Regard
less of the location. A aOkite murdered IN
NesV York by a Negro without brovoc0taon
is inst as distastetul as Negro killed IN
Mississippi for no cause by a uhite.

the locks, took a last careful look
and loaded our Rambler coupe.


1t was about nine-thirty Tues
day morning when we headed to-
ward the automobile supply shop
to buy a travel rack. We COM
pleted our packing at the parking
lot joining the supply house. We
headed north--this time | had to
pick up my stole. But, once again,
had forgotten to get our pre-
scriptions from Openshaws
Pharmacy. Back to the southend
we drove again.


Before leaving the Alaska Fur
Store, | remembered to call Dor
othy Hagmaier at the printing
shop. l had suddenly reviewed
the paper in my mind and realized
had missed title. She howled
with disbelief because she thought
we we're surely far out by this
time. 1t was exactly eleven
thirty--two hours since we had
departed from home. We headed
to Highway 1910 and started the
first leg Of our trip to San Fran
cisco.


No matter how many times you
leave home, the thrill of journey
is always just like the first time
away from home. My spouse and
settled down for the 800 miles
northwest.


The desert panorama rushed
past after we passed Peoria and
the stretches of divided highway
doomed like giant ebony snakes on
the brown sand.


America Is a land of roverS.
There were travellers on both
sides of the highway with destina-
lions far and near. America is
a country Of transporters. Trucks
bringing and taking food and ma
terials keep the roads busy.


Seekers Of recreation we're on
everyside. Boats, campers and
motorcycles took to the open
road. also.


There are no more ma jestic
sights than the great purple and
black mountains Of Arizona.
When the skyline falls on top of
them, one wonders why he could
grab up canvas, palette and oils
and create a masterpiece.


With periodic stops we pulled
into Los Angeles about six-thirty.
We decided to forge ahead to Ba-
kersfield. The last miles we're
.rought, the traffic was getting
heavier and more trucks were
heading out.


Stopping at a motel before
reaching the city. we ate a sand
wich, bathed and tucked our
weary sleeves into bed.


Early the next morning we
started again westward and made
excellent time to San Francisco.
The ocean from the Golden Gate
Bridge appeared hundred miles
deep. We we're in slight fog
and the ships moored made a
grand sight.


The hotel where convention
headquarters were located was
across from San Francisco In
ternational Airport. We drove
past Candlestick Park to the
hotel. 1t seems a strange place
for a baseball park, but many
strange things occur in the Col
den State.


Edward and Iwere among early
arrivals at the Thunderbird
Hotel. We dressed and visited
E. Washington Rhodes, NNPA
president, in his room. Later,
we had dinner.


While we we're in the dining
room Mr.. and Mrs. Frank Nit
chell, publishers Of the St. Louis
.>nr,,e ooroo IL ood cor az On

Sights and Sounds
ELolse BANKS
California, We Come

ON Wednesday, July first, the city sales tax
Was Increased ON purchases from one half Of
one per cent to one per cent. This raises the
entire taxes paid to four per cent wl'tch tn
ch4des the per cent tax imposed BY the state
for sales and education. Thus, each time
sale is made in the city q total Of four per
cent viii be paid by the consumer.


Phoenix's city council ordered this in
crease in order to finance the cost OF pro-
viding municipal government services. The
increase i'm annexed territory and the up
surge in population haze made the contToll-
ing of the streets, crime, traffic and other
cityaOide programs extremely difficult.


We realize that unless the nearby cities,
such as Tempe, Glendale and Mesa do not
levy q city sales tax comparable to Phoe-
nix's then many purchases wiu be made out
side Of the city limits.


Phoenix retailers Wil lose many d0IMTS
and the city 1Viu suffer in the end unless otheT
cities i'm the Valley refrain from wooing Phoe-
nix consumers.

Carlton Coodlet left no stone
unturned to please the conven-
tioneerS.


The cohost, Leon Washington,
of the Los Angeles Sentinel, de-
voted lot of his time to making
sure everyone was pleased.


continued next week
